document.heading: Stockbridge-Munsee Community, et al. vs. Kamille Davids

aside.p: Lay Advocates; Subject Matter Jurisdiction; Timely; Notice of Appeal; Filing Fee

Are Lay Advocates held to the same standard of rule compliance as is required for licensed attorneys in the Stockbridge-Munsee Tribal Court System? Does this Honorable Court have the jurisdictional authority to waive condition-precedent mandates to subject matter jurisdiction?

On April 20th, 2021, the Stockbridge-Munsee Tribal Court entered a final judgment against Appellant Davids. On May 20th, (30 days after final judgment) Appellant Davids emailed a notice of appeal, through her Lay Advocate. On June 9th, (51 days after final judgment) Appellant Davids paid the filing fee. The Appeal was deemed filed on June 9th because the fee was paid. On July 21st, the Community moved to dismiss because the appeal was filed late.

On July 26th, the Court of Appeals dismissed the case because 1) the appeal was not filed timely, 2) Lay advocates must follow the "same general rules that apply to attorneys," and 3) the Court of Appeals lacks subject matter jurisdiction for appeals that are not timely filed.

First, the appeal was not timely filed because S-M e-Filing Rules require an appeal within 30 days of the final judgment, and Appellant Davids did not appeal within 30 days. While Appellant Davids sent the notice of appeal within 30 days, they did not pay the filing fee within 30 days.

Second, the Court of Appeals found that lay advocates must follow the general rules of the court becuase, even though they are not attorneys, they are duly-recognized representatives of their clients. Thus, the Court adopted the rule that "Lay Advocates must comply with statutory mandates when representing clients in the Stockbridge-Munsee Tribal Court System, just as licensed attorneys must meet said mandates on jurisdictional matters such as filing deadlines, statutes of limitations, ethics requirements and ordinance adherence."

Third, the Court of Appeals held it lacked subject matter jurisdiction for this case because the appeal was not timely filed. Thus, the Court of Appeals dismissed the case with prejudice for lack of subject matter jurisdiction.
Held this Honorable Court lacks subject matter jurisdiction

1. "Lay Advocates must comply with statutory mandates when representing clients in the Stockbridge-Munsee Tribal Court System, just as licensed attorneys must meet said mandates on jurisdictional matters such as filing deadlines, statutes of limitations, ethics requirements and ordinance adherence."
2. The Stockbridge-Munsee Court of Appeals does not have subject matter jurisdiction if the "notice of appeal was not timely filed because the filing fee was not timely paid."

caption.h4: In the Court of Appeals for the Stockbridge-Munsee Community Band of Mohican Indians at Bowler, Wisconsin

container.heading: ORDER DISMISSING APPEAL
container.text: On April 20, 2021, the Stockbridge-Munsee Tribal Court, speaking through the Honorable Chief Judge Travis Miller, entered a "Decision and Order for Money Judgment" in favor of the Plaintiff/Appellee and against Defendant/Appellant. For the following reasons, this appeal must be dismissed.

container.heading: RELEVANT FACTS
container.text: A final judgment was entered against Defendant/Appellant, Kamille Davids, ("Appellant"), and in favor of Plaintiff/Appellee, the Stockbridge-Munsee Community, o/b/o Education Department, ("Community"), for reimbursement to the Community for funds paid for college tuition for Appellant. This ruling was entered on April 20, 2021 and constitutes a final judgment for appeal purposes pursuant to TCT.03.03(a)(1). On May 20, 2021, Appellant, through her Lay Advocate, emailed a notice of appeal to the Clerk of this Court on May 20, 2021, at 3:27 p.m., but filing fees did not accompany this lodged filing. The filing fee was eventually, (but untimely), paid by Appellant, and the appeal was finally deemed filed with the Court, on June 9, 2021.

The Stockbridge-Munsee Tribal Court, in response to COVID-19 Pandemic, established Civil Procedure Rules for e-filing pleadings effective June 15, 2020. These rules are found on the home webpage of the Stockbridge-Munsee Tribal Court. S-M e-Filing Rule 6(a), in relevant part, states the following:

text.strong: If a party fails to pay the applicable filing fee, the matter will be deemed not filed and no further action taken.

container.text: [Italics in original text]. On June 9, 2021, Appellant paid the filing fee for the lodged notice of appeal. On July 21, 2021, the Community moved to dismiss the Appellant's late-filed notice of appeal.

para.text: Are Lay Advocates held to the same standard of rule compliance as is required for licensed attorneys in the Stockbridge-Munsee Tribal Court System?
Does this Honorable Court have the jurisdictional authority to waive condition-precedent mandates to subject matter jurisdiction?

container.heading: DISCUSSION - LAY ADVOCATES
container.text: Lay advocates may represent clients in the courts of the Stockbridge-Munsee Tribal Court System pursuant to TCT.01.10(b)(4). A Lay Advocate must be licensed by the Community and approved by the Chief Judge of the Stockbridge-Munsee Tribal Court pursuant to TCT.01.11(c). It does not appear disputed that Appellant's Lay Advocate met the above-cited conditions to act as representative for Appellant.

Tribal courts acknowledge that the same general rules that apply to attorneys practicing in the tribal court system must be followed by Law Advocates. See e.g., In Re: Sekayumptewa, 1997 Hopi App. Lexis 2 (Hopi Ct. App. 8/29/1997), at *26 to *27; Lonetree v. Hoist, 1999 Ho-Chunk Supreme Lexis 15 (Ho-Chunk Sup. Ct. 4/28/1999), at *14; Cleland v. Ft. Peck Tribal Court, 1987 ML 5 (Ft. Peck Ct. App. 1/6/1987), at *5; and Oneida Bingo & Casino v. Palm, 2002 Oneida App. Lexis 49 (Oneida App. Comm. 9/9/2002), at *2. This Court adopts a rule that Lay Advocates must comply with statutory mandates when representing clients in the Stockbridge-Munsee Tribal Court System, just as licensed attorneys must meet said mandates on jurisdictional matters such as filing deadlines, statutes of limitations, ethics requirements and ordinance adherence.

container.heading: DISCUSSION - SUBJECT MATTER JURISDICTION
container.text: Subject matter jurisdiction is a condition-precedent to a court having the power to consider a case. See e.g., W.J. Lazynski, Inc. v. Dept. of Indus., Labor & Human Rels., 332 N.W.2d 313 (Wis. App. 1983) (table) and Sieber-Benson v. Conf. Tribes of Coos, 2008 Coos Confederated Trib. Lexis 2 (Conf. Coos Ct. App. 7/10/2008), at *2. The timely filing of a notice of appeal is jurisdictional and non-waivable by this Court according to TCT.03.06(a) and TCT.03.04(a)(1). Pursuant to Rule 6(a) of the S-M e-Filing Rule, Appellant's notice of appeal was not timely filed because the filing fee was not timely paid. Therefore, this Court is without subject matter jurisdiction to consider this appeal because all conditions-precedent to the appeal being timely filed were not met by Appellant and the Tribal Court did not allow the matter to proceed in forma pauperis. Therefore, this appeal is DISMISSED.
IT IS ORDERED that the above-cited appeal is dismissed with prejudice because this Honorable Court lacks subject matter jurisdiction to hear said appeal.
